thread.title: HS TENNIS: Teams advance to form all-Lackawanna finals
thread.title_full: HS TENNIS: Teams advance to form all-Lackawanna finals

author: JOBY FAWCETT / STAFF WRITER
title: HS TENNIS: Teams advance to form all-Lackawanna finals
text:
Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link Lightbox link 
KINGSTON — The Lackawanna League made a big statement in girls tennis Tuesday. 
Competing in the semifinals of the District 2 Class AA and the District 2-4 Class AAA subregional, four teams representing the league advanced to today’s finals at 3:30 p.m. at Kirby Park. 
In Class AA, top-seeded Scranton Prep defeated No. 4 Valley View, 3-0, and No. 6 North Pocono upset No. 2 seed Wyoming Seminary, 3-1. 
In Class AAA, fourth-seeded Wallenpaupack ended the undefeated season of No. 1 Hazleton Area, 3-1, and No. 3 Abington Heights knocked out District 4 representative Williamsport, 3-1. 
All matches were contested indoors at Kingston Tennis Club due to inclement weather. The lengthy semifinal matches also forced the final to move to today. 
North Pocono battled Wyoming Seminary in the last of Tuesday’s semifinals. 
In the lone singles win for North Pocono, Annika Treitz defeated Abbey Capin, 6-3, 6-2, to get the team started. 
The Lady Trojans then swept the doubles matches as Brooke Panek-Haley Zernek defeated Megha Sarada-Emily Laurore, 6-3, 6-4, and Morgan Carney-Aurora Monacelli beat Megna Melkote-Kelsey Kayton, 7-5, 6-4. 
“It was an amazing feeling, because I get really upset sometimes in a match,” Treitz said. “I just did what my coach has been telling me to do since I started playing when I was 7 years old. 
“It clicked. I moved my feet and was hitting all of my angles. I stayed focused and paced myself.” 
Scranton Prep is back in the final in search of its seventh straight team title. 
Emily Jonsson, the reigning District 2 Class AA singles champion, defeated Cali Craig, 6-0, 6-0, and Maansi Malhotra beat Alyssa Santarelli, 6-1, 6-0, and the Classics, who reached the PIAA Class AA final last season, clinched the win at No. 1 doubles as Tatiana Klacko-Mira Patel defeated Gabriella Barber-Courtney Mackrell, 6-1, 6-0. 
“I am so excited, because this is my senior year,” Patel said. “This was definitely the best that we all played so far this season.” 
Class AAA 
Hazleton Area won the coin toss for the No. 1 seed, held before the teams took the court. 
But, it was Wallenpaupack that seized its opportunity. 
Irene Gendelman gave the Lady Buckhorns the early advantage by staying unbeaten at No. 3 singles by defeating Sofia Losen, 6-3, 6-2. 
Wallenpaupack clinched the victory with a pair of wins in doubles. Kristen Denniston-Phoebe Cykosky defeated Jessica Wenner-Adrianna Bohman, 6-0, 6-2, and Gina Nolan-Heidi Washburn set off the celebration after a grueling win over Sayaka Ishibashi-Kimberly Delregno, 5-7, 6-2, 6-4. 
“We started off kind of rough, but we finished tough,” Washburn said. 
“We fixed our mistakes, that was the key,” Nolan said. “Once, we settled in, we did pretty good.” 
Abington Heights advances to the final where it will be seeking its sixth straight title. 
Lauren Carroll gave the Lady Comets a win at No. 3 singles, beating Alisha Chen, 6-0, 6-1. 
“I am just honored to play in districts, because last year, I wasn’t a starter,” Carroll said. “I went in and was really nervous, so I just tried to shake it off and play my game.” 
The Lady Comets sealed the victory with a pair of straight-sets wins in doubles. 
Caroline Hickman-Catherine Pusateri beat Kathleen Kinley-Kelly Hoffman, 6-1, 6-4, while Ajna Prahalad-Rachel Muir beat Madison Helier-Christine McFadden, 6-1, 6-1, to hand the Millionaires their first loss of the season.
